The Committee on Appropriations Resolution under the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include Committee suballocations for appropriations after consulting with the other House's Committee on Appropriations. The Committee on Appropriations Resolution is amended to include suballocations for appropriations in a joint resolution, detailing allocation of budget outlays and new budget authority among subcommittees. The joint resolution includes suballocations for appropriations among subcommittees and follows procedures for consideration in the Senate. The joint resolution reported under this paragraph in the Senate will follow the provisions of section 305 for consideration, with debate limited to 20 hours and managed by the Committee on Appropriations. The joint resolution reported under this paragraph shall be limited to 20 hours of debate and managed by the Committee on Appropriations. The allocations of the Committees on Appropriations will not take effect until the joint resolution is enacted into law. After a concurrent resolution on the budget is agreed to, all committees except Appropriations must subdivide their allocations among subcommittees or programs they oversee, in consultation with the other House's committees. After a budget resolution is passed, committees must subdivide their allocations among subcommittees or programs they oversee and report the subdivisions to the House. Amendments are made to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 regarding committee allocations and subdivisions. Amendments are made to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 regarding committee allocations and subdivisions, including alterations proposed by the Committee on Appropriations. Amendments to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 allow for alterations of allocations proposed by the Committee on Appropriations, subject to approval and consistency with previous actions taken by the House. Amendments to appropriations bill. Amendments to appropriations bill include changes to Section 302 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974, allowing for floor amendments that reduce budget authority and relevant subcommittee allocations. Amendments to appropriations bill can reduce budget authority and relevant subcommittee allocations, impacting discretionary spending limits for the fiscal year. The bill allows for reductions in budget authority and relevant subcommittee allocations, affecting discretionary spending limits for the fiscal year and the following four years. It also restricts the consideration of conference reports containing such provisions in appropriations bills passed by both the Senate and the House of Representatives. The conference report on an appropriations bill includes a provision reducing subcommittee allocations and discretionary spending. It is not allowed to consider a conference report that does not include such reductions in allocations and spending. The Senate and House cannot consider a conference report on an appropriations bill without reductions in subcommittee allocations and discretionary spending. SEC. 4.
